note.p: Ridgley C. Powers served as governor of Mississippi from 1871 to 1874.

Born in Mecca, Ohio, on December 24, 1836, Powers was raised and educated in the north. In 1862, after receiving a degree from the University of Michigan, and conducting graduate work at Union College in New York, Powers enlisted in the Union Army for service during the Civil War. He was promoted to second lieutenant and then captain in the 125th Ohio Infantry Regiment and saw action in Tennessee and Georgia. By the time the Civil War ended in 1865, Powers had achieved the rank of colonel.

Upon separating from the military, Powers settled in Mississippi. He purchased land and began a cotton plantation. He soon became a public figure, serving as sheriff in Noxubee County. By 1868, Powers had gained status in Mississippi’s Republican Party, and was elected lieutenant governor in 1869. Although he was a “carpet bagger” (northerner who settled in the south during Reconstruction), Powers was generally respected by white Mississippians. This was in contrast to Governor James Alcorn, a northern by birth, but who was considered a “scalawag” since he had lived in Mississippi since the 1840s and had served in the Confederacy before joining the Republican Party. When Alcorn resigned the governor’s office in 1871 to take a seat in the U.S. Senate, Powers assumed the state’s executive office. He became active in promoting Mississippi’s economic development and independence, advocating crop variety and lesser dependence upon imported goods. Despite his efforts to maintain a stable political and economic environment in Mississippi, a rift grew among Republicans that led to competing party nominations for governor in 1873. Alcorn was nominated by the more conservative wing of Republicans against Adelbert Ames, former Union general and military governor, who was backed by the radicals. Ames won the election and took the governor’s seat in 1874.

In 1875, shortly after leaving office, Powers married Louisa Born. The couple had one child who died in infancy. They moved to Arizona, but Louisa suffered from a mysterious medical condition and began traveling across the United States and Europe for treatment. She passed away in New York in 1882 after undergoing surgery. Powers later remarried (to Mary Wilson) and moved to California. He spent the rest of his life as a rancher and businessman at Los Angeles. He died on November 11, 1912, and is buried in Angelus Rosedale Cemetery in Los Angeles, California.

Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

Located in Warren County, Mississippi, Vicksburg was founded under the name Fort Nogales as early as 1790 in what was then unincorporated territory. In 1798, upon creation of Mississippi Territory, it was renamed Walnut Hills. On April 1, 1799, Walnut Hills became part of the newly created Pickering County (later renamed Jefferson County on January 10, 1802), until the creation of Claiborne County on January 26, 1802. It then became part of its current county of Warren on December 21, 1809. Upon its incorporation on January 29th, 1825, it was renamed Vicksburg. Vicksburg became the county seat in 1836 and remains today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 858; Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Cook County, Illinois, Chicago was incorporated on August 12, 1833 and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located in the east-central interior of North America, the Great Lakes are a series of interconnected freshwater lakes. They touch the Canadian province of Ontario and the U.S. states of Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New York. The Great Lakes are the largest group of freshwater lakes on Earth by total area, with a combined area of 94,250 square miles. The five individual lakes in the Great Lakes are Superior, Michigan, Huron, Erie, and Ontario. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The Great Chicago Fire of 1871 was one of the most deadly urban area fires in American history. It started in the evening of October 8 in a small barn owned by the O’Leary family near DeKoven Street. One popular myth claimed a cow kicked over a lantern, but the exact cause was never determined. The flames spread rapidly among Chicago’s wooden buildings, which were largely covered with highly flammable tar and shingle roofs. A summer drought had left conditions drier than usual and strong winds carried the fire into the heart of Chicago. Although the city had a fire department, a watchman mistakenly sent the first responders to the wrong part of Chicago. By the time firefighters reached the actual fire, it had spread out of control. It raged for more than twenty-four hours, before it largely burned itself out. Fire fighters and an evening rain on October 9 extinguished the final flames. The conflagration covered an area roughly four miles long and three-quarters of a mile wide. It destroyed approximately 17,500 buildings, and more than $220 million in property. As many as three hundred people died in the fire, although only 120 bodies were found. Ninety thousand people were left homeless.

During the initial aftermath, Chicago’s mayor placed the city under martial law. Lieutenant General Phil Sheridan arrived to command a military force comprised of regular soldiers, militia, and civilian volunteers, to prevent looting and maintain order. The military force patrolled Chicago and retained martial authority until October 24, 1871. People from across the United States and in Europe donated to Chicago’s relief effort. City officials also revised fire codes and emergency services, turning Chicago into a model community for fire fighting professionalism. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: This term refers to the relation, often but not always wives and children, of a person imprisoned in a civilian institution, ranging from jails to penitentiaries.

Impoverished people are those who lack "a usual or socially acceptable amount of money or material possessions," or alternately those who "lack the means to satisfy their basic needs (Britannica). This definition, necessarily subjective and broad, indicates that what one person or society deems "socially acceptable" or what constitutes "basic needs" is malleable.

Similarly, impoverished people in the United States in the nineteenth century did not fit one specific category. The rise of industrialism produced an increased number of impoverished people in the U. S., particularly within large urban centers. European immigrants in cities in the East, and Chinese immigrants on the West Coast, and African Americans in the South were disproportionately affected by poverty. Regionally, the highest number of impoverished people came from the U. S. South, where "both whites and African Americans struggled with debt, low cotton prices, laws favorable to employers and creditors, paltry alternatives, and the general post war devastation" (Encyclopedia of the United States in the Nineteenth Century, Vol. 2, 547).

Racism and nativism among employers and employees also made economic advancement more difficult for people of color and immigrants. However, the impoverished made up a comparatively low percentage of Mississippi's antebellum population, given its low number of immigrants and even native residents, lack of industrialization and urbanization, and mobility of those that were impoverished (Mississippi Encyclopedia). Many reform organizations throughout the country took the lead in fighting poverty in the nineteenth century, while state and federal governments by the end of the century also developed its own institutional responses. The status of being impoverished has always carried negative connotations in American history, so CWRGM uses the tag "Impoverished people" to emphasize the personhood of those in poverty rather than their social status.

div.p:
Miss State Prison
Jackson Miss Feby 12th 1872

To
His Excellency
R. C. Powers Governor &c.
I respectfully beg leave to lay before your Excellency, the following statement of my Case, in the hope of receiving your Excellency's Clemency.

I was arrested in Vicksburg in november-'66 along with Thomas, Halsted, and Dennis O'Brien whom your Excellency pardoned from this institution last december, on the charge of having stolen pro-perty in our possession, after remaining in the County jail for nine months we were brought to trial and convicted, and sentenced to this prison for five years. I received no justice during my trial, being a northern man, the court there-fore being preedjudiced against me, not allowing any evidence to be heard that was in my favor but receiving all evidence that was sure to Con-vict me. I have now suffered over five years

imprisonment for having goods in my possession that I presented a bill of sale of during my trial, but Judge Magar, would not allow the bill of Sale to be brought in as evidence of my not having Known that the goods were Stolen, when I bought them. I am from Chicago, Ills, your Excellency, and my mother with a family of three small children were still in Chicago when I last heard from them. I am therefore suffering great anxiety & suspense regarding them since the distruction of Chicago by fire. My mother was poor and lived in that part of the city which was totaly distroyed

I am a steam Boatman by occupation and came South in the fall of 66, on account of navigation having closed on the lakes, intending to work on the Mississippi River Boats until Spring and then return to Chicago, as I could always find employment on the lake steamers.

Therefore having already suffered for even five years in prison, I would beseech your Excellency to grant me your Clemency, and permit me to return to chicago where I can support my mother and her children, I am a good mechanic now,

your Excellency, and will be able to work my trade and support my mother & family. hoping your Excellency will allow me to return to my mother as I am sure, that, my mother & family are suffering at present and are very much inneed of my care, and assistance. if your Excellency will therefore remit the remainder of my time now a little over Six months, as I was sentenced on the 14th" day of August, 1867, I will immediately return to Chicago, and support my mother, and my little brothers & sister
hoping your Excellency will grant my humble prayer & petition
I have the honor to be Your Excellency's humble Servant
